bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to James Carroll, February 14, 1901

div1.p: Howard identifies the bee that Carroll had sent to him earlier, giving specifics about its range and habits. He looks forward to talking with Carroll and Reed about the success of the yellow fever experiments, and wishes them success in identifying the organism that causes yellow fever. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to James Carroll, February 14, 1901
div1.p:
I have your note and the accompanying box,
which contains a specimen of one of the carpenter bees, known
as Xylocopa cubaecola, a species which occurs throughout the
West Indies and extends into Central America. In fact, I have
taken it myself, in large numbers, on the Gulf of California,
at Guaymas. It bores tunnels in wood and lays its eggs in
cells separated from each other by caps of sawdust soldered
together.

I am looking forward to a talk with yourself and Dr. Reed,
and feel almost as enthusiastic as you must feel over the won-
derful results of your experimental work. I earnestly hope that
you and no others will be the first to discover the true or-
ganism of yellow fever.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L.O. Howard Dr. James Carroll, U. S. A.,
Camp Columbia,
Cuba.
